The best Murphy beds are among the most versatile, space-saving furniture items on the market, giving people the choice to have a discreet sleeping area in a guest bedroom, home office, or playroom. They’re kind of like the mullet of the interior design world: Business in the front, slumber party in the back.

When it’s closed, a Murphy bed looks like a desk, cabinet, or chest, and frees up plenty of floor space. Sometimes referred to as wall beds, these have handles or some other feature you can pull down to reveal a bed frame and mattress.

“Murphy beds are all the rage once again, but with a different take on design and function,” says Ania Agárdy, a Miami-based interior designer who runs the AD PRO Directory firm Luxury Living by Ania Agárdy. “Actually, they have become much more multifunctional than in the past, providing not only additional shelving and storage, but also integrated sofas and desks.”

Daniella Hoffer, AD PRO Directory designer and owner of Daniella Hoffer Interiors, says custom is preferred, but you can elevate any Murphy bed sold online by color washing the entire wall, enlisting trim and millwork experts for retrofitting, or adding cohesive decor.

“Creating millwork on the wall or making it look like cabinetry—similar to how we approach pantry doors in the kitchen today—is a beautiful way to incorporate a Murphy bed into the space, and frankly, hide it,” she says. “Or even putting a piece of artwork that you can remove easily before pulling down the bed.” Ahead, find all of our expert-approved picks for your home.

Our Top Picks for the Best Murphy Beds:

  • Best Overall Murphy Bed: Bestar Pur Murphy Bed, $1,500

  • Most Stylish Murphy Bed: Wildon Home Solid Wood With Rattan Murphy Bed, $1,400

Please note that prices reflect queen-size beds. However, most of the featured frames are available in additional sizes and finishes.

How We Chose the Best Murphy Beds

For a comprehensive understanding of Murphy beds, we turned to designers Ania Agárdy, Daniella Hoffer, and Sarah Storms for their shopping tips and specific product recommendations. From there, we explored best-selling, top-reviewed products on the market today and analyzed a number of accounts from real customers. We prioritized the functionality and style of each piece, and took note of special features that could appeal to homeowners.

FAQs

What to look for in a Murphy bed

Here are the key components to assess while you’re shopping for a Murphy bed, per our research and feedback from Agárdy, Hoffer, and Storms.

  • Function: Think about the space and your expectations. Who will use this room, and is there an alternative purpose for it? “I have been using them frequently in empty-nester households where the children’s rooms have been redesigned to serve as multi-purpose spaces like a guest room/office or guest room/gym, or both,” Agárdy says. Hoffer also sees Murphy beds in secondary homes, such as a summer house.
  • Style: Evaluate your home and the overall design elements you’ll need to coordinate with prior to purchasing your Murphy bed. Fortunately, there are plenty of styles to choose from, so you’ll find one for a midcentury modern guest room, bright and eccentric children’s room, and so on. “I always look for ones that can be customized to blend with the overall look of the room,” Agárdy adds.
  • Size: While Murphy beds are space-saving by nature, sizes can range depending on the functionalities. For instance, a Murphy bed with a cabinet or desk attached will take up significantly more room (closed or open) than a classic Murphy bed without those bonus bells and whistles. You’ll also need to factor in the size of the mattress you’d like, since there are Murphy beds that can accommodate twins to kings. Make sure to measure your space prior to checkout.
  • Installation: The customer reviews don’t lie—even the best Murphy beds are a pain to install, and some even require a specific type of wall for proper mounting. It’s technically one piece of furniture, but it comes with lots of parts and most manufacturers (and our design experts) recommend a professional installer. If you feel up to the DIY challenge and the manufacturer gives you the okay, follow the instructions and exercise as much patience as possible. Otherwise, enlist a pro to help you out. Because of the installation requirements, this is not considered a renter-friendly solution.

What’s the best type of mattress for a Murphy bed?

“There isn’t any reason to sacrifice quality sleep and wall beds can be just as comfortable as a traditional frame, as long as the platform and mattress are solid and supportive,” Storms says.

Storms says any high-quality mattress will do, and Agárdy often suggests hybrid mattresses for support and comfort.

“Getting the right size can be tricky. Choose one on the thinner side (10 inches or less) to ensure it fits when folded,” she says. “I normally go with the Murphy bed manufacturer’s recommendation to ensure the fit is just right. They are all different, so the standards do vary according to the model.”

Are Murphy beds really worth it?

Perhaps the most overwhelming concern is whether Murphy beds are safe. While there have been recalls over the years due to unexpectedly detaching and posing crush hazards, most modern Murphy beds are made with locking legs to keep them down or up (if it’s in use as a bed or not). With that in mind, if you can afford the investment and need a more open room in your home, experts say it’s worth the splurge.

“I think it all depends on your particular budget and lifestyle needs,” Agárdy says. “If the room is small but fully furnished and you just need some extra walking space, then a wall bed frame would work perfectly.”

For a more personalized approach to the Murphy bed, both Storms and Hoffer say places like California Closets offer more semi-custom solutions to seamlessly blend these pieces into your existing interior design.

How do wall beds compare to Murphy beds?

Traditionally, wall beds featured wood frames and pistons, while Murphy beds often used metal frames and springs. Compared to Murphy beds, wall bed frames are more budget-friendly and easier to install, since there are fewer parts involved. Agárdy issues a warning, however, that they’re not quite as aesthetically appealing and are more difficult to integrate into an overall room design. “Murphy beds are full systems where the bed folds vertically into a cabinet or closet, often with shelving or a desk attached,” she says.
